XmKHKqVuB5qJa6RpPIweqg.text: As a local Singaporean, I recommend our friends from overseas to try out the stalls selling fried oyster, the Ang mo kio Yong Heng fried hokkien mee, and sin min road rong chen bak kut teh. The food are truly amazing and good representation of Singapore street food. I did not have the stomach to try out all the stalls. I will post again when I am here for meals next time.

BZgGsFLZ-ciLbxC9_Yks4w.text: For the experience itself, this is a pretty nice area to stop by after you're done with the Singapore Flyer. Situated right under the Flyer, this entire area is located on the first floor. Modeled similar to a hawker centre, you'll see different food stalls lined up. Prices here are a wee bit higher than the usual stalls at other hawker centers. For the food options, there is a huge array of typical Singaporean dishes, some Indonesian food, Chinese and desserts. For food, I tried the laksa (prawn noodle soup) and found it quite lack luster. The broth was blander than expected and not worth the price. As for the dessert, I tried the ice ball and found this to be pretty unique!! The ice is shaved and used to form the ball. Within the ball, are a variety of different jello like things and red bean. For the different colors, each syrup had a unique taste to it. I highly suggest trying out this dessert if you're in doubt of trying other dishes. Another suggestion I have is, when in doubt at what to eat, follow the locals and see where they line up or what the majority of the people are eating. This usually indicates if the food is good / popular and most of the time, you really can't go wrong :)

photos.caption: Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. Plenty of seating space
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. Laksa... A bit bland for the broth.
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. Ice ball! On the inside, is jello like things and red bean. Each of the coloring on the ice has its own flavor as well.

JA4diKpPMErGeCnJfOFu4g.text: This food court area is located below the Singapore Flyer! I went here just before lunch time and it was pretty empty. Most of the stands were open at this time so there was quite a bit of selection to choose from! I'd recommend dining at these food plazas when in Singapore since it's a great way to sample some Asian cuisine! (They're pretty much everywhere and some are even open for 24 hours!)I ordered the roasted chicken over rice dish since I was craving it and I wanted to try a legit version besides the ones I've eaten on the plane, lol! Anyway this place is filled with cheap eats!!!! The chicken and rice dish I ordered was under $2USD *good portion and I was able to eat more after my walk to the Marina*!

photos.caption: Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. Roasted chicken over rice!
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. Roasted chicken and rice!

gSzhslUq281MnkuUP-Of1w.text: The only decent dish I had at the Singapore Food Trail was the Broiled Chicken Rice at Bugis Street Famous Hainanese Chicken Rice stall. The local prawn noodle at Newton's tasted like Raid Ant Spray. We were given food vouchers as part of tour and had $20 SIN dollar to spend. For the rest, I spent it on drinks and Satay at the Old Airport Road stall. Overall, unappetizing and disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore

Kapf7Vh_5Zuch_qpL_7KTA.text: Good sampling of Asian cuisine on the first floor of the singapore flyer. Some of the stands are clean with adequate food covers. Some of the food served were freshly made; some were sitting out in the open. This is basically a throwback fast food court. Nice staff. I had the  shaved ice with red bean which was what i need due to high humidity.Accessible.

KeQsn4UbQE1hr5ViQKYe0g.text: The Singapore Food Trail was a great find under the Singapore Flyer for a late dinner of traditional Singaporean cuisine.  Yeah, it's probably touristy, but it sure beat wandering around late in the dark in an unknown area to find a place for dinner.The 2 of us shared a Hainanese chicken rice, oyster omelet, and a snow ball that was akin to ice kacang.  Tons of stuff--beans, gelatin, syrup, etc.--hidden inside the ice, and I was a bit surprised to find a sweet corn topping as part of this dessert.  The oyster omelet was way too oily and not quite reminiscent of previous encounters in Taipei, but the other two dishes were pretty good.I also saw a stand selling Dragon Beard peanut candy--a childhood favorite of mine--but alas, my tummy was too full to pack in another sweet.On the way out, I saw a bunch of people waiting in line for bak kut teh, a pork rib soup made with a variety of Chinese herbs and spices.  Looked so yummy and healthy, but sometimes pigs just can't eat another bite.  :P

photos.caption: Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. snow ball like an ice kacang with TONS of stuff hidden under the ice...  and sweet corn on top!
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. WAY too oily oyster omelet
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore. Hainanese chicken rice

juOILH4Y_O0BdJxfsxnmmg.text: This is such a cute little food court. I came through during the daytime so the place was virtually a ghost town. The vendors were really nice and I enjoyed a dish of rice and poor belly for $5 SGD -- very affordable pricing.

eOPHwt7jfq-lbhOAA-6M_A.text: Hawker Centre for the Tourist - aka tourist trap. What else would one expect from a food centre below the Singapore Flyer? It does offer a reasonable selection of local foods at reasonable prices. I got the minced meat noodles. It was good. Not AMAZING, like i have had elsewhere in singapore, but i have realized that if you can name the place easily on a site like Yelp, then it probably isn't going to be amazing. It's good enough though if you are looking for things like bak kut teh, oyster omelet, grilled seafood skewers, etc.

photos.caption: Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore

lQo2jLIKobPpwFczhBFhIQ.text: Stay away from the Singapore Food Trail. Although it is well promoted by lots of people, it is not worth going. The food is more expensive than other hawker centres and it is not very close to the MRT (especially in the sweltering heat). There are also not many options available to eat either. ANY other hawker centre would have been better to this one.

photos.caption: Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Singapore Food Treats - Singapore, Singapore

3qSVy20QUp7bQPDpD7WVvA.text: I have always wanted to visit the Singapore Food Trail, which is a 1960s themed food street at Singapore Flyer and Food Republic Beer Garden at Harbourfront when they opened in early 2011. There was much hype when they opened but it seemed to have died down. Before this, our visit to the Food Republic Beer Garden was disappointing as only a few stalls were opened on a weekend evening and the customers were sparse.In fact, I have forgotten about this place until I chanced upon an ongoing promotion through its Facebook page recently. One item from each stall was at $2.50 instead of $5--cheaper than those at most Food Republic food courts. Since there are substantial savings, I decided why not head there for a try?The noodles of the Satay Bee Hoon ($2.50) are well-strained so it was not too wet. More of that piquant gravy would be wonderful. Apparently, the stall that began since 1950s is famous for its gravy made from 15 ingredients, but lard is no longer used.The East Coast Lagoon Rojak was the star of that day. To be honest, we liked it more than the Kovan Rojak because the sauce had the right consistency and a well-balance sweet and tangy taste. The best thing was the you tiao (dough fritters) which stayed fresh and crunchy till the endInstead of Sambal stingray, we ordered the Yang Zhou Fried Rice from Boon Tat Street BBQ since it was the dish on offer at $2.50. Nonetheless, the rice was fluffy and spicy, with a strong whiff of wok hei.From the Bugis Street Ah Huat Hainanese Chicken Rice stall, we ordered half-a-chicken instead of the $2.50 plate of chicken rice as the Folks wanted more meat. The meat was tender and good, but not much different from those outside. Conclusion: Food here are delicious and it is a relief to see that most stalls are still manned by Singaporeans--the owners or their relatives. Price wise, they are similar to Food Republic without using the discounts. But many of the stalls were either closed (eg. Ann Chin Popiah ) or had permanently stopped operations. With an air of gloomy atmosphere among the hawkers, I hoped that the online promotions (till May 31st) can help to improve the business. But whether such concepts are sustainable in the long run remain a question

tvXc4noZDMykZttC2e9zCg.text: Hit and miss I think, depending on which stall you go to. The satay stall is pretty good (though I've yet to find a hawker centre who does bad satay). Chicken and mutton, both delish. Got a laksa from one of the stalls (can't recall which) - really wasn't to my liking so it got tossed. Ended up just getting a garlic naan from the Indian stall (yum - but I guess you can't really go wrong with naan). Conveniently close enough to the hotel to walk (albeit, and outdoors sweaty walk). However, next time, I'll just head to the esplanade hawker instead.
